Ortmann received his B.A. in anthropology from South­ern Illinois University in 1995 and his Ph.D. in anthropology from Tulane University in 2007. Thomas J. Pluckhahn is an associate professor of anthropology at the University of South Florida. He has interests in the archaeology of households, ceramics, and landscapes. His work centers on the east­ern United States and mainly on the Woodland-­period societies of the Gulf of Mexico. Mark A. Rees is a professor of anthropology and head of the Department of Sociology, Anthropology & Child and F amily Studies at the Univ ersity of Louisiana at Lafayette. He is the editor of Archaeology of Louisiana and a coeditor, with Patrick Livingood, of Plaquemine Archaeology. Kenneth E. Sassaman is the Hyatt and Cici Brown Professor of Florida Archaeology at the University of Florida. His long-­term interest in the Archaic societies of the lower South­east has been expanded recently to the north Gulf Coast of Florida, where he and his graduate students are examining the 4,000-­year-­long history of living with the environmental and social challenges of sea-­level rise. He is the author of The East­ern Archaic, Historicized, and a coauthor, with David G. Anderson, of Recent Developments in Southeast­ern Archaeology: From Colonization to Complexity. S. Margaret Spivey is a graduate student in the Department of Anthropology and the Ameri­can Culture Studies Program at Wash­ing­ton Uni­ver­ sity in St. Louis
note: She is also a citizen of the Pee Dee Indian Nation of Beaver Creek. Her work focuses on the interplay between the social complexity of hunter-­gatherer societies and the built monumental landscape in the south­ east­ern United States. Spivey received her B.A. in anthropology from Harvard College in 2008 and her M.A. in anthropology from Wash­ing­ton University in St. Louis in 2011. Index

He has conducted ar­chaeo­logi­cal fieldwork through­out east­ern North America, in­clud­ing multiple field seasons at Poverty Point and related sites. He is a contributor to Archaeology of Louisiana and has extensive experience in cultural resource management, in­clud­ing excavations at the Troyville site. Christopher R. Moore is an assistant pr of essor in the Depar tment of Anthropology, Physics and Earth-­Space Sciences at the University of Indianapolis. He received his Ph.D. from the University of Kentucky in 2011.His interest in the Green River Archaic stems from his doctoral research, which involved a detailed study of bone and antler tools from the Baker and Chiggerville sites. Currently he is co ncerned with understanding the social, po­ liti­cal, and material consequences of human interactions in vari­ous contexts ranging from the east­ern Archaic to Spanish colonial settings to nineteenth-­ century rural America. He has authored numerous scholarly papers, in­clud­ing articles in the Journal of Social Archaeology and World Archaeology
